div1.head: Jim to M. Paul Rockwell June 10th ‘15
div1.p:
One of the ladies in this town is leaving for Paris with a lot of refugees and I am sending this down by her to be mailed from there. Nearly all the civils are gone now which is most sensible. The bombardments are so bad of late that the hospitals have been closed and now we have to evacuate all the way to Dieulouard. Following an attack the work is very hard for we have to creep at night along a road jammed with artillery caissons, and supply trains.
I was an actor in the show that resulted in the closing of the largest ambulance. I’d just run into the court yard, and a doctor had come up to me as I was getting ready to leave, when we heard a marmite that was going to hit close to us. She banged down a hundred yards from us and removed the second story of a house, killing a few people. We crouched to avoid the eclats. The doctor said “Come inside” I followed him into the corridor that runs the length of the front of the hospital.
No sooner had we entered than I saw two men that were standing near the next arch entrance to the one we had passed into the corridor by, crouch swiftly against the wall inside. I don’t know exactly whether I heard the whistle or not but I do know that suddenly the air turned into a crushing solid that took my breath away. There was a terrific detonation and it became dark. Glass, pebbles, dirt and plaster pelted me from all directions and I wondered what was coming next. I expected the wall. Then
I heard shrieks above the din of falling debris and thru [sic] the clouds of smoke and dust a man tottered towards me, yelling and crying like hell. He grabbed my shoulders and sobbed like a little child that a dog has scared. He hadn’t been hit. It was the unnerving effect those big shells have. When it cleared up I saw nothing but wreck and ruin around me. Two of our group were down. One was lying very still and a stream of blood flowed from him and eat its way thru [sic] the
thick layer of dust on the floor. An eclat had gone right thru [sic] him. The other died afterwards. Some others were wounded. I wasn’t touched. The 210 had exploded 25 yards from us. Fortunately it hit in the court yard just before reaching the wall we were behind, otherwise I wouldn’t be here. Of course you’ve seen a lot of em [sic] in the trenches but it gets you nervous to have the blooming things roar on in when one’s above ground. 69 came in after that. There were about 50 casualties.
Did I write you about the pleasant voyage I had to the Gros Chene where they bury the dead, and about fishing two Boches out between the first and second line trenches?

I was up in the first line at the Col de Cygne where some of the most terrific fighting of the war has been going on. By the way a bunch of those Greeks from the 1st Etranger sneaked over to the Boche line the other night carrying only knives and they cut up quite a bunch of Germans before going back.
When do you reckon, if you are doing any figuring, the big affair is coming off? I was talking with Salisbury about chances of getting down to it and I think I can get off for a day if no big attack is staged at the same time. I’d have to know about 2 weeks ahead tho [sic] in order to get my papers and a letter from you full of important names would help considerably.

Do I understand that you’re going to get K
transfered [sic] to Paris in the near future.[?]

Wonderful weather out here now and things are moving well. The last attack gave us command of the Norroy road and we can shell hell out of the German supplies. The last bunch of prisoners look seedier than ever. One told me he thought the gig was up and that Germany couldn’t hold out much longer. Personne ne sait Mon Ami.

closer.salute: Wonder what sort of a note America is going to bluff with next.
